title: Font clashing with ancient computer....
content:
First time poster/font creator here.

I have designed a simple handwriting typeface for a project, it's not much but it's a key element of a brand I'm creating. I used Fontlab Studio and generated a Truetype font which works perfectly on my Mac and has been tested on a PC too, no problems.

Unfortunately I've encountered a label printer who is using an antique PC running Windows 98 which is telling her that there's a problem with it, but is of course being vague about the nature of the problem.

I don't have a PC so can't run any diagnostics on the font to see what might be causing this incompatibility. If anyone out there can have a quick look at the font file here [http://www.mediafire.com/file/r2ozdj2mgdx/G&S Script 02.ttf](http://web.archive.org/web/20100203174755/http:/www.mediafire.com/file/r2ozdj2mgdx/G&S%20Script%2002.ttf) and tell me what's wrong I'll be eternally greatful.

I know the font doesn't look like much on its own, but it's an integral part of a brand I'm creating for a new client.

Thanks  
T
author: schneish

comments.content:
What if it was the "&" and the spaces in the filename?  
I can't test it on a Windows 98, but I'm just guessing it could be a filename issue.
You know what, it probably is that simple. I'll get her to test it out.

Maybe you'll want to run your font through the [MS Font Validator](http://web.archive.org/web/20100203174755/http:/www.microsoft.com/typography/FontValidator.mspx). It shows quite a few technical issues in your font.
The font is named with a numeral 2 in the PSName. This is out of spec and is most likely causing the problem. Substitute Two for 2 in the PSName and I bet that solves the problem.
Also, your style name is not set to Regular. Another breach of normalcy that might have an impact on your end user.
